New-York Historical Society
Stanley R. Rosenberg Architectural Records PR 254
3.22 Linear feet (6 boxes & 4 oversize folders)
1952-1985, undated, (bulk 1954-1974) Materials in this collection may be stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit. Architect Stanley R. Rosenberg worked with several architectural firms, including Hausman & Rosenberg, designing a variety of buildings such as community centers, synagogues and high-rise office buildings.
Provenance
Gift of Stanley R. Rosenberg, 2006.
Access Restrictions
Materials in this collection may be stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
Use Restrictions
Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.
Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.
Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions
Preferred Citation
This collection should be cited as: Stanley R. Rosenberg Architectural Collection, PR 254, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.
Biographical Note
Stanley R. Rosenberg (b. 1923) attended Brooklyn College from 1941-1943 before obtaining his Bachelor of Architecture from Columbia University in 1952. He worked in several architectural firms before becoming a partner in Sirof & Rosenberg in 1954, which became Sirof, Rosenberg & Sivertsen in 1955. Rosenberg held an individual practice from 1958 to 1960. In July 1960 he joined with architect Alvin W. Hausman, forming Hausman & Rosenberg Architects. The two worked together on projects ranging from community centers to high-rise office buildings, until the firm dissolved in 1977.
Scope and Content Note
The Stanley R. Rosenberg Architectural Records span the period from 1952-1985 and primarily contains photographs, slides, negatives and printed material related to architectural projects designed by Rosenberg and his various architectural firms. Projects include apartment buildings, community centers, firehouses, hotels, offices, private residences, restaurants, schools, stores and synagogues. The collection is divided into three series: Stanley R. Rosenberg Project Files; Hausman & Rosenberg Project Files; and Office Files.
Arrangement
Files are arranged alphabetically by project name.
Related Material at the Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections
Additional architectural project and office files can be found in the following collections: Cass Gilbert Architectural Collection (PR 021), McKim, Mead & White Architectural Record Collection (PR 042) and George B. Post Architectural Record Collection (PR 052). Additional photographs by Richard Averill Smith can be found in the Mattie E. Hewitt & Richard A. Smith Photograph Collection (PR 026).
Correspondence. Architecture -- United States -- 20th century. Architectural drawings (visual works) Dwellings -- United States -- Design and plans. Fire stations. Housing authorities. Synagogues -- New York (State) -- New York. Bronx (New York, N.Y.) Brooklyn (New York, N.Y.) Commercial buildings -- United States -- Designs and plans. Rosenberg, Stanley R. Smith, Richard Averill
Series I: Stanley R. Rosenberg Project Files
Scope and Contents note
Series I. Stanley R. Rosenberg Project Files contains photographs, slides, negatives and other printed material, mainly publicity, related to projects done by Stanley Rosenberg as well as the firms Sirof & Rosenberg and Sirof, Rosenberg & Sivertsen. Images include both photographs of finished projects as well as copy photographs of presentation drawings. Projects include Avenue Z Jewish Center & Talmud Torah, Harbor Hills Country Club, Manhasset Lakeville Firehouse, and Monaco Surf Club. Richard Averill Smith photographed the Harbor Hills Country Club; his negatives and prints are located in this series.
Oversize material includes mounted photographs of the Canon Camera Showroom and the Harbor Hills Country Club and reproductions of presentation drawings for an unidentified commercial project as well as the Mack Residence. Oversize flat files contain two presentation drawings for Eastwood Village and one presentation aerial perspective drawing for the Hodson Community Center.
Several 8" x 10" negatives from this series are severely deteriorated. These negatives have been separated for conservation reasons, and can be found in Box 5, Rehoused Negatives. 6-8 East 53rd Street, New York, NY1130th Street Office Building, New York, NY12Ardsley Motel, Ardsley, NY13

Scope and Contents note
Series II. Hausman & Rosenberg Project Files includes visual and printed material for projects designed by the firm of Hausman & Rosenberg. Copy negatives and photographs of presentation drawings make up the bulk of these files. Research material and slides of completed projects are also included. The firm designed animal hospitals, apartment buildings, libraries, office buildings, schools, and synagogues. Projects include the Lincoln Square Synagogue, Eleanor Roosevelt Houses and several branches of the Trade Bank & Trust Company.
Oversize material includes photographs of Brookdale Institute for Talmudic Studies, Cryder House, the 1964 World's Fair Hell Drivers Exhibit, Trade Bank & Trust and Vitarine Pharmaceutical Branch. Presentation drawings include a reproduction of a drawing for the firm's Lido Beach Apartment project and original drawings of a storefront at 601 Madison Avenue and the Engine Co. 9, Ladder Co. 6 firehouse. A reproduction of a presentation drawing showing the Cryder House lobby is located in the Oversize flat files.160 Water Street, New York, NY240215 West 125th Street, New York, NY241Appellate Court addition, New York, NY242Bier Veterinary Hospital243Bradley International Hotel244Branford Hills Apartments, Branford, CT245Brookdale Institute of Talmudic Studies of the Rabbi Jacob Joseph School, New York, NY246Brookdale Institute of Talmudic Studies of the Rabbi Jacob Joseph School, Riverdale, NY247Brooklyn Public Library, Greenpoint Branch, Brooklyn, NY248Camden office building, Camden, NJ249Camer Glass, Light fixture250Castle Hill Jewish Community Center, Bronx, NY251Congregation Sons of Israel, Yonkers, NY252Cryder House, Queens, NY253-54

Scope and Contents note
Series III. Office Files include articles, newspaper clippings, and reference images for various projects, from Rosenberg's various firms. Also included in these files are portraits of Stanley Rosenberg, correspondence, and paperwork related to Rosenberg's certification as a registered architect with the National Council of Architectural Registration Boards in various states.
Oversize material included in this series has been separated and stored in flat file folders.Articles written by Stanley R. Rosenberg1957-1969490Artist Information1967, 1972, n.d.491
